description: Also known as Sultan Ahmed Mosque, this architectural masterpiece built in 1616 features six slender minarets, cascading domes, and over 20,000 blue Iznik tiles that give it its iconic name. A perfect blend of Byzantine and Ottoman architecture, it remains an active mosque in the heart of Istanbul's Sultanahmet Square.
highlights: Over 20,000 blue and white Iznik tiles decorating the dome and upper walls creating the signature blue interior
Six minarets - unique in Ottoman history and originally controversial for matching Mecca's Grand Mosque
Magnificent dome measuring 23.5 meters in diameter with 260 windows flooding the interior with light
Intricate Islamic calligraphy and geometric patterns throughout the prayer hall
Spacious courtyard with colonnaded peristyle matching the mosque's interior dimensions
Location directly opposite Hagia Sophia in Sultanahmet Square
tips: Open daily 8:30-11:30, 13:00-14:30, and 15:30-16:45 (closed during prayer times)
Closed to tourists during Friday prayers, especially around noon
Women must cover their heads with a headscarf
Both men and women should wear modest clothing covering shoulders and knees
Remove shoes before entering (plastic bags provided for carrying them)
Visit early morning or late afternoon to avoid large crowds
Sunset visits offer mesmerizing views of the mosque against the evening sky
Be respectful: no loud noises, phone use, running, or flash photography
Do not photograph worshippers praying inside
vibe: Serene, sacred, and breathtaking. The soft blue glow from thousands of tiles, cascading natural light through hundreds of windows, and the quiet reverence of worshippers create an atmosphere of spiritual tranquility that transcends religious boundaries.
expectations: A tourist attraction first, place of worship second
Similar experience to visiting Hagia Sophia
reality: An active, functioning mosque where worship takes priority over tourism
Access restricted during five daily prayer times, especially Friday afternoons
Free entry unlike many other major Istanbul attractions
More peaceful and less commercialized than expected despite its fame
unique_facts: Sultan Ahmed I personally worked on the construction, even carrying soil himself between 1609-1616
The six minarets sparked controversy as it matched Mecca's Grand Mosque; an extra minaret was added to Mecca to resolve the issue
The name 'Blue Mosque' comes from the blue tiles, but locals call it Sultan Ahmed Mosque after its patron
Legend says the architect misheard the Sultan's request for 'gold' (altın) minarets as 'six' (altı) minarets
The mosque took seven years to build and Sultan Ahmed I died just one year after its completion at age 27
It was the last great imperial mosque built in the classical Ottoman style
surprises: Entry is completely free unlike most major historic sites in Istanbul
The interior is even more stunning than photos suggest when sunlight streams through the windows
The mosque continues to function as an active place of worship, not a museum
Plastic bags are provided to carry your shoes while exploring inside
The nearby Hagia Sophia, once the mosque's Christian counterpart, now faces it as a mosque as well
The courtyard is almost as large as the mosque itself and equally impressive
